Problem:
Consider an electrical circuit with a resistance R in series with an inductance L and a varying voltage source V(t). The voltage and current relationship is given by the differential equation \\(V(t) = L\\frac{dI}{dt} + RI\\), where I is the current through the circuit.

If at a certain time \\( t_1 \\), an additional resistance \\(R_2\\) is introduced into the circuit as an intervention, will the current I(T) for T > t_1 depend only on the original voltage source \\(V_0\\) and not on the introduced resistance \\(R_2\\)?
Explanation: The introduction of an additional resistance \\(R_2\\) changes the total resistance in the circuit which affects the ratio of the voltage drop across the resistors to the inductor, thereby altering the rate of change of current and the final value of I(T). Thus, I(T) will depend on both \\(V_0\\) and \\(R_2\\).
